text: surgery today would be impossible
without general anesthesia but doctors
and scientists still don't know how
anesthetics work to figure things out
they've been using tadpoles for a
century now a new molecule that freezes
and wakes tadpoles on command could help
provide some answers it's based on
propofol an anaesthetic hospitals use
every day I won't deny that i'm not an
expert in anesthesia chemist direct
rohnert makes molecules to control
elements of the nervous system he
learned about propofol searching for a
way to control gaba-a an important
protein in the brain now he's
collaborated with anesthesiologists to
make a version of propofol that changes
shape with light just like propofol it
puts tadpoles under but at a flash of
blue violet light and the anesthetic
wears off instantly enough that the
tadpoles start swimming again without
light though the molecule switches back
and the tadpoles go back under blue
violet light doesn't reverse the effects
of propofol other types of light like
yellow light don't work at all Ivan
mahasti who studies anesthetic
mechanisms says the new probe is much
bigger than both propofol and previous
anesthetic probes so it has more
elements chemists could mess with when
designing future probes this is an
exciting paper I think because it really
shows the power of using small molecules
to someday be able to figure out exactly
the mechanism by which general
anesthesia works
